content.description:
Believe it or not this is a chimney with three chockstones in it.  These chockstones, and other crack features make this route quite leadable.  A decent beginner route if you happen to be in the area. 

 RCM&W #24, p.37.
content.protection: Standard rack, should length slings for slinging chockstones.  Standard top rope setup.
content.location: This route is the obvious chimney with three chockstones in it.  It is the furthest left (south) route on the buttress.

content.description:
Follow the crack.  Those not wanting to use offwidth/chimney technique will find many pleasing features within and outside the crack. 

 RCM&W #26, p.37.
content.protection: Leadable but you'd need big stuff, a #4 camalot would be your microcam.  Standard top rope setup.
content.location: This route is the crack in the corner to the right of 5/8.

content.description: Start on the obvious pillar without use of triple chockstone and climb the face straight up good crimps and sidepulls with a lower crux
content.protection: standard bm toprope but good lead with large cam down low and small nuts and micro up top in thin crack on right side
content.location: left of triple chockstone start on obvious pillar

climbs.name: On a roll (a.k.a. Lichen No Other)

content.description: Start on the arete under the roof. Pulling the left side of the roof passed a lichen covered sidepull. Continue up through strenuous terrain to the top.
content.location: Located to the right of the gambler and left of 5/8 on the arete

content.description: The face and arete right of The Squeeze. Start with good ledges on the left side of the face moving up and across the face (crux) above the small overhang, continues straight up using the right arete.

The name says it all.  Layback the crack.  A fun and challenging route.  Usually done as a top rope problem, but could be lead if someone was so inclined. 

 RCM&W #27, p.37.
content.protection: Small stuff to protect the crack.  Standard top rope setup.
content.location: To the right of The Squeeze lies a roof with a thin crack.

content.description: Climb up easy holds in the corner to a crack which splits the underside of the roof.  Find some feet then use the crack and some face crimps (crux) to pull the roof.  Follow just left of the arete to the top.
content.location: Obvious roof just right of Kanaranzi Left and left of The Corner.

content.description: 4 feet right of K-1 is a thin black crack in the middle of the face. Go straight up until your about even with the roof, about two-thirds of the way up then bail right (easier) or continue straight up (harder).
content.protection: Long slings and some creativeness.  Setting up the anchor requires an exposed class 3 scramble across a chimney.

content.description: The roofs and arete add more exposure than you usually find here.  There is a dihedral at the junction of the south and east faces. Climb the corner up to the first roof, go right, then up the east-facing crack to the upper roof (which can easily be made harder, but hardly made easier).
content.protection: I would have a lot of large pro. Up around the second roof there is a beautiful pothole you can thread with a sling. There is another large pothole that can be slung for an anchor.  Better yet, just walk around back, climb the fairly easy Class 3 chimney to set up a top-rope.
content.location: Start on the south face near the corner, its pretty hard to miss.

content.description: Immediately right of The Layback is a wide chimney.  K-1 ascends a flake on the right side of the chimney. When the flake ends, improvise straight up.  It's possible but easier and less aesthetic to stem the chimney behind you.
content.protection: Long (20+ feet) slings are recommended to sling the large boulder above this route.  Setting up the anchor involves some exposed class 3 scrambling across the chimney.

content.description: Start 4 feet left of The Layback. Surmount the roof and follow the arete above.

The Gambler is a slightly squeezed but independent line that slices up the left side of the face between Triple Chockstone and On A Roll.  Begin up easy climbing to a ledge.  Fire straight up through some sequential edges and sidepulls on the face left of the black streak.
content.location: The face right of Triple Chockstone.

content.description:
A fun and interesting climb.  Follow small holds up and over and overhang.  Avoid cacti as best as possible as you surmount the overhang.  There is a large loose block about halfway up, but its been that way as long as anyone came remember.  There was a bat within screaming bloody murder when I pulled on it. 

 RCM&W #25, p.37.
content.location: This route is on the face to the left of the squeeze and around to the corner right of Triple Chockstone.

content.description: The south face of the Kanaranzi Buttress contains several high quality climbs ranging from 5.5 to 5.11.  The bottom of this area is protected from the sun, although the top halves of the climbs do see sun throughout most of the day.  The top of the cliff sees plenty of sun as well, so the sunscreen might come in handy while setting up top ropes. The placements tend to be a bit spread out in this area, so bring plenty of webbing.
